Title: Wealth Shown To Scale
Brief_Description: Scrollable long blocks, representing wealth of richests people in USA
Short_Des: It encodes the wealth data of the median US household income, Jeff Bezos, and the richest 400 Americans using a linear scale of $1 per pixel. Each data item is represented by a rectangle. All data items are lined up horizontally. audience use keyboard interaction to scroll from left to right to fully view each data item. There is a scroll bar in the bottom such that the audience can Jump or skip the scrolling.
Data: The wealth data of the richest people in USA.

Title: 8 Billion People In Perspective
Brief_Description:
A 3D animations where the camera moves through the entire world population as a huge
crowd assembled in a vast area
Short_Des: The video presents the world population. A camera with the overhead angle moving backward reveals 3D human models that represent all humans forming a giant square. There are models of city buildings and famous landmarks like Eiffel Tower scaled to compare with the human crowds. The video ends with an overview of the square.
Data: The world pupulation when it reaches 8 billion.
Note: - it is the camera moving. so the mark is still?

Title: Risk, Cycling And Denominator Neglect
Brief_Description: Scrollable cluster of blocks representing bike journeys
Short_Des: In this visualization, every human icons represents a trip a bicycle. It shows all bicycle journeys made in 2012 in Greater London. 25,000 trips on a bicycle are grouped as a block, the average number of trips made every hour in Greater London. Every 13 blocks are grouped in a larger block, representing 325,000 journeys which averagely has 1 serious injury. The audience can scrolled down to see the whole visualization.
Data: Number of bike trips and trip incidents in 2012 in Greater London.
Note: - kind of boring case. And the key message is not about sense the magnitude but finding specific data points burried in a large mark

Title: Yale'S $32 Billion Endowment
Brief_Description:
A 200-meter-long strip painted on a street, comparing Yale University’s its $32 billion endowment to
its contributions to its home city of New Haven
Short_Des: The visualization is a bidirectional bar chart on the ground. One side of it is the bar that represents Yale's $32 billion endowment, while the other side is the bar that represents Yale's paltry $13 million contribution to the city of New Haven. The audiences walk along side the bar to sense how long the bar is.
Data: Yale's $32 Billion endowment compared to its paltry $13 million contribution to the city of New Haven.

Title: Des Dinosaures À L'Homme (From Dinosaurs To Humans)
Brief_Description: An animated timeline visualization of the universe in a monitor goes forward as the viewer turns the crank
Short_Des: Museum visitors are invited to turn a handle to explore major events from the first appearance of dinosaurs to their extinction and going on to the appearance of human ancestors up to today. The scale used is linear so that it requires a long time to navigate from the time of dinosaurs to the modern time.
Data: Timeline of major events from the beginnings of dinosaurs to today

Title: The Historical Cost Of Light
Brief_Description: Scrollable pixels representing the cost of light during different eras
Short_Des: Each pixel the audience scroll through is equivalent to a second of work for an average waged worker in America. The audience will try how long they need to scroll to gain an hour of lumination based on the salary in 2020,1800s, and 2000BC.
Data: How long people need to work to afford the cost of an hour's light in different centries.
Note: - it is an unusual mapping from time to pixels to time. it's abstract to understand sometime.

Title: Hiking Path Of The Solar System
Brief_Description: A hiking trail featuring a scale model of the solar system where every meter corresponds to one million kilometers of actual distance.
Short_Des: The path is designed on a scale of 1:1 billion and thus offers a clear representation of the sizes and distances in the solar system. One meter of the model corresponds to one million kilometers in reality. The planetary path includes not only the planets Mercury , Venus , Earth , Mars , Jupiter , Saturn , Uranus and Neptune , but also the dwarf planets Ceres and Pluto .
Data: The sizes of planets in the solar system and the distances between them.
Note: - For I cannot experience the case myself, some designs are unknown

Title: Trail Of Time
Brief_Description: Walkable path illustrating the time elapsed leading to the Great Canyon formation
Short_Des: "The start of the Trail of Time is at Yavapai Geology Museum, a half hour walk from Mather Point and the Canyon View Visitor Center." Visitors "will start by walking the 'Million Year Trail', which transitions from human time scales to geologic ones. The 'Million Year Trail' is immediately followed by the main Trail of Time where each meter equals one million years of Grand Canyon's geologic history. This fully accessible one hour walking trip provides breath taking vistas of Grand Canyon and allows you to ponder and understand the depths of geologic space and time."
Data: The time of the Grand Canyon's geologic history mapped into walking distances in the Grand Canyon.

Title: The Fallen Of World War Ii
Brief_Description: Video moving along vertical bars representing the number of death soldiers during World War II
Short_Des: Starting from 05:43, the camera moves up to reveal a long bar representing the death number of the Russian military during WWII. When the camerve moves up, a zoom out movement is accompanying.
Data: The number of death caused by World War II in different countries.

Title: The Deep Sea
Brief_Description: A scrollable infographics showing how deep the sea is and animals living at different depth levels
Short_Des: As the audience scroll down, the audience see the cutout images of marine animals at deeper level of the sea. A horizental line at the bottom part with a number show to suggest how many meters deep the position of the line represents.
Data: How deep different marine animals live in the sea.

Title: The Actual Number Of Americans Jailed Or Imprisoned
Brief_Description: Scrollable pictograms representing the actual number of Americans imprisoned
Short_Des: In the website, every human icon represents an America in jail (the collected data time is unsure). As the audience scroll down, the accumulative number of people icons has been shown is updated at the right top corner of the website. The website also overlay related statistics, facts and charts in front of the human icon background to give more details.
Data: Statistics related to Americans in jailed.
Note: - Maybe we should say there is a minimal differentiable efforts/time to say a case is binded to time/efforts

Title: A Virtual Reality 360 Experience Case From An Experiment
Brief_Description: Video of a bar charts representing tea production per country.
Short_Des: A 360° VR video where viewers explore a 3D bar chart from a spaceship. Bars, scaled as 1x1m tea cubes, rise in real-world proportions. The ship moves dynamically, including upward, for optimal viewing. The case is downloaded from: https://immersivedatavideo.github.io/
Data: The amount of tea production by countries.
Note: - For anchor, I labeled visual, as I have another version of this video with anchors but no large camera movement

Title: The Incredible Depth Of Earth Layers
Brief_Description: Animated video of a bar representing the depth of the Earth and its layers.

Title: All People On One Page
Brief_Description: Scrollable area covered in pictograms representing the current world population.
Short_Des: Each human icon in the website represents one human. At the top is the estimated number of people living on Earth, updated in real-time. The website adding new icons at the top from let to right. The audience scrolls down and left/right to look through all icons. When the mouse is hovered in an icon, a tooltip next to the cursor shows the total number of people born until that icon is generated.
Data: The number of people living on Earth.

Title: Death In Syria
Brief_Description: Scrollable area covered in dots representing killed people during the syrian civil war.
Short_Des: Each red dot represents a peron got killed in the war.
Data: The number of people killed in the four-and-a-half-year Syrian civil war (reported at Sept.14, 2015).

Title: 7 Billion People On 1 Page
Brief_Description: Scrollable unit visualization where each icon represents an individual in the world, colored according to their continent of residence
Short_Des: Each human icon in the website represents one human. Different colors represents different continents. The audience can scroll vertically and horizontally to look through all icons.
Data: Number of people in the world when it reaches seven billion.
Note: - I ended in 3mins becuase that's when I felt boring and lost. It can be a typical example that without narratives or other enhances.

Title: Du Papier Toilette (Oui Oui...)
Brief_Description: Urolling a toilet paper roll to compare sizes of different digital media presented by the length of paper sheets
Short_Des:
"I start with a sheet representing 60 MB and cut it in 2 several times to give different sizes until I get to an email without attachments.

Then I ask the assembly how many sheets would be needed for 1 hour of video on Netflix in HD. I unroll and give the answer, stopping at 50 sheets (3 GB)."
Data: What is the size of different digital media in KB?

Title: All Of The World’S Money And Markets In One Visualization
Brief_Description: Scrollable visualization of squares representing world's money
Short_Des: In the visualization, each square represents $100 billion. It shows the world's money and market distributted in different categories like countries, continents, sectors and so on.

Title: If The Moon Were One Pixel
Brief_Description: Planets of the  solar system is laid out left-to-right, using a “moon = 1 pixel” scale
Short_Des: Moon is scaled as a pixel in the screen. Based on this scale, the visualization presents planets in the solar system from left to right. The users can horizontally scroll the website to examine the distances between different planets and their sizes.
Note: - "In case you're wondering, you'd need about 2000 feature-length movies to occupy that many waking hours.", "You would need 665 of these screens lined up side-by-side to show this whole map at once". It has many interesting narratives to keep me scrolling. i ended up with draging the progress bar and stop whenever there is a text

Title: O Cálculo De Uma Tragédia (The Calculation Of A Tragedy)
Brief_Description: COVID-19 deaths in Brazil as dots stacked by day over time
Short_Des: Each dot represents a person who died from COVID-19 in Brazil. The dots are arranged in chronological order, grouped by the day each death occurred. From top to bottom, the number of dots represents the number of deaths as time progresses. The visualization also overlays the figures of cars and trains to illustrate the scale of the tragedy, showing how many vehicles would be needed to accommodate the number of people who died during certain periods.

Title: What If I Told You: You Eat 3496 Litres Of Water
Brief_Description: A long pictogram of 15400 bottles of water that people consume everyday
Short_Des: The icons of 15400 bottles that represent 15400 liters of water are stacked up to represent a large wall of bottles.
Data: Litres of water for producing food (e.g.,  to produce 1 kilogram of boneless beef we need 15400 litres of water)
Note: I would hope there is a final zoom out to see  the difference between the wall and a human. - When both vis and anchor are concrete, it creates anchor in both data and physical space (but it undermines the massviness of data by using small icons of bottles intead of real-world scale)

Title: 500,000 Lives Lost
Brief_Description: A large scrollable bee-swarm plot, showing COVID-19 deaths over time
Short_Des: Each dot represents a person who died from COVID-19 in USA. The dots are arranged in chronological order, grouped by the day each death occurred. From top to bottom, the number of dots represents the number of deaths as time progresses. On the top left, there is a mini-view of the visualization and the current position where the viewers are.

Title: Sea Level Rise By The Numbers
Brief_Description: A long pictogram of Olympic-size swimming pools,  representing the 76.6 trillion gallons of metlwater due to climate change
Short_Des: The visualizations use a pictogram of Olympic-size swimming pool to represent 660,000 gallons of water, 1,000 pools, or 1 million pools. Only in the last case, it is possible to show how much swiming pools should be presented to represent the 76.6 trillion gallons of metlwater.
Data: The 75.6 trillion gallons of meltwater from Greenland’s ice sheet between 2002 and 2017

Title: Number Of Deaths In The WW2 Per Country
Brief_Description: A 3D animation where the camera moves through a series of 3D bars.
Note: Markscanning only happens in few single bars

Title: Us Debt Of $20 Trillion Visualized In Stacks Of Physical Cash
Brief_Description: A 3D animation where the camera moves through stacks of money representing US debt

Title: Ocean Depth Comparison
Brief_Description: Video explaining how deep the ocean is by introducing several famous depth locations
Note: - The final overview is a good practice

Title: Turkey'S Toxic Dust
Brief_Description: Zoom-out animation of an area representing damaged buildings in Turkey after 2023 huge earthquake.
Data: Weight of dust caused by the earthquake in Turkey

Title: Space Elevator
Brief_Description: Scrolling website presenting the layers of the atmopshere.
Note: For those combined both a mark (length, distance) and concrete visualizations, I tend to be distracted from marks easily.

Title: The Data Physicalization Of Wealth Shown To Scale
Brief_Description: Physical cubes present the wealth of normal and richest Americans

Title: Climbingchart
Brief_Description: A bar chart displayed vertically across several floors of a building through AR

Title: Walkingchart
Brief_Description: A bar chart displayed horizontally over several meters of a parking lot through AR

Title: Augmented Reality Waste Data Representations
Brief_Description: A augmented-reality pile of trash bags.
Related Part (if applicable): The Animated panning in the beginning where trash bags fall down one by one at constant speed

Title: Global Plastic Waste 1950-2019 - Data Visualization
Brief_Description: Plastic bottles accumulation between 1950 and 2019.

Title: The Search For Answers
Brief_Description: Scrolling visualization of plane wreckage at the bottomo of oceans

Title: Sizing Up Australia’S Bushfires
Brief_Description: Scrolling through squares representing burnt area after australian wildfire

Title: Skyfall - Tracking The Asteroids That Menace Earth
Brief_Description: Scrolling through the Earth-Moon distance to understand how far past and future asteroids pass from the Earth

Title: Proxemics Interaction
Brief_Description: 2D-screen visualization showing bar charts based on the distance between the screen and the viewer
Short_Des: Showing data in a screen. "Small data visible up closer; large data only visible from far away"
Note: Brainstorming cases lack details to know data binding types

Title: Take An Elevator
Brief_Description: Viewers taking an elevator with a transparent window through which they can see a bar chart painted on the wall
Short_Des: The viewer is taking an elevator that has a transparent window. Looking out the window there is a chart painted on the wall. As elevator moves up, differents part of the chart are revealed.

Title: Peephole Interaction
Brief_Description: Viewers using a phone as a peephole view through which the viewer can inspect the mark on a wall
Short_Des: The viewer is moving a phone around to scan a wall, and different parts of the chart shows up in the phone's screen like a peephole interaction.
Note: - what should we do when a brainstorming case can for different data binding and scanning types? - The dimentionality of motion can be 2D or 3D, depending on the encoding

Title: Data Driven VR Roller Coaster
Brief_Description: VR roller coaster trails consisting of concatenated stacks of 100-dollar bills, representing the wealth of the richest person in the world.
Short_Des: In a VR  experience, viewers take a roller coster. The length of a roller coster represents the common amount of wealth of different social classes. The larger amount of wealth correspond to larger size of a loop or more numbers of loops.

Title: VR Spaceship Traveling Through The Solar System
Brief_Description: VR trip accross the solar system to visualize distances between planets
Short_Des: In a VR experience, the viewers take a spaceship to go to traveling between planets to understand their distances (scaled).

Title: Comparing Wealth In Stacks Of 100-Dollar Bills In AR
Brief_Description: AR stacks of 100-dollar bills onto a street to compare the wealth of normal and the richest people.
Short_Des: During hiking or cycling in a path, the viewers can use AR to view planets whose sizes and distances are scaled.
Note: - I am hesitated about shortcut, again

Title: Tissue Paper Box
Brief_Description: Physical visualization of a tissues accumulation to visualize waste
Short_Des: The viewer takes tissue out of a tissue paper box. Each tissue represent certain quantity of waste. The tissue pile on the ground is an accumulative amount of waste.

Title: VR Spaceship Circling The Earth Surrounding By Money
Brief_Description:
Viewers taking a virtual spaceship journey around
the Earth that is surrounded by stacks of 100-dollar bills representing the wealth of the richest person
Short_Des: In a VR experience, the money of rich people is layout as circles surrounding a planet. The users would take a spaceship to travel through those circles.

Title: Biking ARound The Planets In VR
Brief_Description: Viewers riding a stationary bike to circle around down-scaled planets in virtual reality to compare their sizes
Short_Des: In a VR experience, the viewers ride a bike o go a full round outside a planet the size of which is scaled.

Title: Queuing With All People In The World In VR
Brief_Description: VR visualization of the world population all in a queue, moving forward each time an inhabitant quit the queue
Short_Des: Imaging in VR all people in the world form the same queue, and the viewer is at the end. Every time when one person in begining left, the viewer moves forward in the queue.

Title: Go Up Stairs And See The History
Brief_Description: Vertical timeline representing humankind history accross several floors, requiring to climb stairs

Title: Escape From A Room Where Money Fall From The Sky
Brief_Description: Cumulative view of money filling a VR room
Short_Des: In VR, the viewers need to escape from a room where piles of money fall from the sky.

Title: Data As Virtual Flow
Brief_Description: Flow getting through a VR room
Short_Des: The viewer pushes a button, and there will be a virtual flow of water or sand representing data cascading from the top and filling the space where the viewers are.

Title: Convey Belt
Brief_Description: Marks painted on a convey belt or physical marks carried by a convey belt
Note: Depend on how long it takes, there maybe mental efforts (bear the board)

Title: Marks On Streetcars
Brief_Description: Marks painted on streetcars (e.g., trams) move in and out the field of viewers
Note: - Can the train itself as an anchor? - For locus of control and locomotion, if people can walk to see the train body from end to end, it becomes user-driven and physical moving.

Title: Dragon Dance
Brief_Description: Bar charts painted on traditionnal Chinese dragon-dancers
Note: Different from train, dragon dance case doesn't stop at a place. Normally, people do not rely on their locomotion to scan the mark.

Title: Visualization Shown On The Screen Of A Treadmill
Brief_Description: Horizontal bar charts displayed on a 2D-screen moving forward by running on a treadmill
Short_Des: (NOTES) or stationary bike

Title: Moving Up An Elevator Through Fixed Pulleys In VR
Brief_Description: Vertical bar charts displayed outside a VR elevator going up by pulling up fixed pulleys
Short_Des: (NOTES) can give a sense of vertical distance. Can also be used for diving (pulling oneself from a rope)

Title: Diving In VR
Brief_Description: An VR experience where viewers mimicing diving with a descend line to see how deep is sea
